content.description: A difficult move off the ground leads to a hand/finger crack, then you get easier but steep climbing to the top. Watch for loose rock near the bottom of the crack, as well as at the topout.
content.protection: Set up a TR anchor on top with hand-size cams and long webbing.
content.location:
It is on the left side of the crag, around the corner from '

Corner Arete

'.

content.description: This is the best route at this crag. It consists of 35 feet of sustained, steep climbing on good rock. The crux comes about 2/3 way up and involves a big move off crimps to a small "finger hole".
content.protection: TR, the anchor takes small cams and nuts, and bring some extendable slings.
content.location: This ascends the obvious, intermittent finger crack that goes up the center of Lone Tree Bluff.

content.description: Climb the right-facing corner on the left side of the wall, utilizing the arete about halfway up. Traverse right at the top of the corner to the top of the crag. Watch for loose rock at the traverse.
content.protection: Scramble around to the north to access to the top of the cliff for a TR setup.
content.location: It is on the left side of the crag.

climbs.name: Chimney
climbs.fa: D. Alexander, J. Persun, S. Kennedy

content.description:
This is a short stem chimney on the far right side of the wall. Scramble around to the north to the top of the cliff to set up a TR anchor.

20 feet of chimney leads to easy ground to the top. Watch for loose rock coming out of the chimney.
content.location: It is on the far right side of Lone Tree Bluff.
